Dialogue: I got...

Dialogue: Guess you don't want to see the greatest show on earth. And in Detroit no less. Well, take care, chief.

Dialogue: Yeah, you're probably too young anyhow.

Dialogue: You have my solemn oath as a public servant.

Dialogue: Hey, chief, you need a ticket? Second row center, seventy-five clams.

Dialogue: Shit! You just skunked my last ball, you...

Dialogue: Please, sir, don't kick my ass! I'll do anything to get out of a beating!

Dialogue: How much cash do you figure?

Dialogue: Take five for a minute, Chongo. Let me do the math.

Dialogue: Shit!

Dialogue: Keep your paws to yourself, ya dumb fuckin' apes.

Dialogue: Consider it done.

Dialogue: Just knock loudly, sister.

Dialogue: Prepare to receive the Act of Penance. How many sins have you committed since your last confession?

Dialogue: Okay, ladies, hang onto your hormones. Here comes our next amateur. Let's have a big hand for Hawk!

Dialogue: You're up, Hawk.

Dialogue: Oh, Dicky, I c-c-can't...

Dialogue: You're not gonna chicken out on me now, are you? We've got your KISS song playing and everything.

Dialogue: I-I c-can't...

Dialogue: Look, people undress in public because, A, they're exhibitionists, B, they're nutcases, or C, they need the money. I can tell you're not A, and I hope to hell you're not B. So my suggestion is, think about why you're a C and let your body party, shake your groove thing, boogie oogie oogie till you just can't boogie no more.

Speaker: hawk
Dialogue: You're right, Dicky. I gotta do it for KISS. Gotta put a bag over its head and  Do it for KISS.

Dialogue: Wow. I feel a hundred times better!

Dialogue: Thanks lady.

Dialogue: Maestro? As you were.

Dialogue: Come on, dude, we got a bunch of frisky felines waiting for some entertainment! The show must go on!

Dialogue: Two hundred bucks?

Dialogue: You heard me, nad breath. My time's precious and I think that's a reasonable price to pay for your sorry life.

Speaker: trip
Dialogue: Look, I want to live, but I don't know where the fuck I'm gonna find two hundred bucks.

Dialogue: Chongo? Take him outside and tear his ass out through his mouth.

Dialogue: Hold on! I know how I can get the money! I just figured it out! Only you might wanna wait outside.

Dialogue: I don't trust him.

Dialogue: I think he's on the level. He's too stupid to try anything sneaky anyway. Look at him, he's a moron.

Dialogue: You got fifteen minutes and not a second longer. We have a concert to go to. See you outside.

Dialogue: Keep it together, Lex. Anything worth fighting for is worth dying for.

Dialogue: WHOOOOAAA!

Dialogue: That's it?

Dialogue: Yeah.

Dialogue: Well, this is a unique confession to say the least, son. And not exactly the most interesting one I've ever heard either. Dialogue: No.

Dialogue: Well then, I suggest you have a seat on the bench behind you and think of something a little juicier to confess than losing KISS tickets. I realize this is Detroit, but I personally find, what that rock and roll band is all about, to be boring as Lucifer's kingdom. I'll return in a little while.

Dialogue: Beth? I can't believe it.

Dialogue: Believe it.

Dialogue: Are you waiting for confession? I thought you were Jewish?

Dialogue: I have a confession. Here it is.

Speaker: beth
Dialogue: I didn't mean for that to be so... intense. Forgive me.

Speaker: jam
Dialogue: I don't care. I wanna hear more.

Speaker: beth
Dialogue: I've loved you ever since I first laid eyes on you, Jeremiah. I've just always been too scared to show it.

Speaker: jam
Dialogue: Beth, I can't believe you just said that because that's exactly how I've always felt about you... Call me Jam. It's my band name.

Dialogue: You don't know how long I've been waiting to hear that... Jam!

Dialogue: We've got to take this slow...

Dialogue: Right, slow...

Dialogue: Oh, screw it!

Dialogue: ...and Mr. Massive Head Wound Accompanied by an Upset Stomach-Hawk!

Dialogue: No contest. The grand prize of seventy- five dollars goes to Troy the Human Jackhammer!

Dialogue: Thanks, miss.

Dialogue: Right, well, thanks for the drinks and stuff, Amanda, but there's no reason for me to stick around these parts anymore.

Dialogue: Don't be so glum, Hawk. The night's still young and filled with plenty of compensatory possibilities.

Dialogue: Huh?

Dialogue: I'd be in a position to spend some money on you if you'd get in a position and spend some time on me.

Dialogue: Where are you, son?

Speaker: jam
Dialogue: Uhh, tying my shoe.

Dialogue: Oh. So, have you thought of a colorful confession yet?

Dialogue: Actually, yes. Last year I walked out of a candy store with a Reggie Bar I hadn't paid for, but went back and apologized the next day.

Dialogue: Boooring. Think, boy, think!

Dialogue: I can't believe you're even thinking of committing a robbery, Trip. You don't pass go and collect 200 dollars for pulling stuff like this.

Dialogue: No shit, dude, is this really worth it? Sure you get your ass kicked nine ways to Sunday by that fucking gorilla, but it's still a hundred times better than getting it porked for the next three to five.

Dialogue: And what about that girl, Trip? She'll never forget this night. Even if you get away with it, she'll be scarred for life. When are you gonna realize sometimes being tough means being tender.

Dialogue: Okay, bro. You gonna have to do this sometime. Might as well be now.

Dialogue: P-p-please, mister, I'm just a high school kid...

Dialogue: Alright, drop it or I'll kick your ass!

Dialogue: The KISS Army!

Dialogue: Oh, God, they're in there!

Dialogue: Dogs! Why did it have to be dogs!

Dialogue: Wake up, Lex! Wake up, man! This part's gotta be a nightmare!

Speaker: lex
Dialogue: God, if you ever get me outta this, I swear I will never masturbate again!

Dialogue: I REALLY MEAN IT THIS TIME!

Dialogue: So. Is it true that Gene Simmons had a cow's tongue grafted onto his real one? Y'know, to make it so long?

Dialogue: I dunno. I think he had the piece of skin under his tongue removed so he could stick it out farther. I'm not too up on Gene trivia.

Dialogue: Peter Criss is my inspiration, man. If I paid a hundred bucks for a KISS show and all I saw was his solo, I'd consider it... money... Hey, how'd you know that?

Dialogue: I have all your notebook doodles memorized, Jam... Here.

Speaker: jam
Dialogue: Ann Arbor?

Speaker: beth
Dialogue: My dad's company is relocating him. We're moving. That's why I was acting so freaky in school today. I thought it was the last time I'd ever see you. Anyway, open the box. I would have given it to you this morning, except... like I said, I was freaking out.

Speaker: beth
Dialogue: I pass by this really cool tee-shirt shop on my way to school every day and I know you wear those black tee- shirts all the time. You look like a size thirty-five, but all the sizes were in Roman numerals. So I got you an XXXL. That's thirty-five, isn't it?

Dialogue: Okay, you better have something really sinful for me this time, son. My patience is worn to threads and your mom will be here any minute.

Dialogue: Alright, Father, here it is. About two weeks ago I went to my cousin's wedding and one of the bridesmaids asked me if I wanted to take a bath.

Dialogue: No...

Dialogue: I was insulted, so I asked her if I was wreaking some wicked b.o., right? Then she said no, she wanted to take a bath with me.
